title: 109_hr6003
content: The "Psychological Kevlar Act of 2006" aims to reduce psychological casualties among military personnel by providing training and support to enhance psychological resilience and decrease susceptibility to post-traumatic stress disorder. The "Psychological Kevlar Act of 2006" requires the Secretary of Defense to develop and implement a plan for preventive measures to reduce the likelihood of combat personnel developing post-traumatic stress disorder or other stress-related conditions. This plan includes incorporating evidence-based practices into training, combat operations, and post-deployment services. The Secretary must periodically update the plan based on relevant research findings. The Secretary of Defense conducts research to develop a plan for preventive measures against combat stress. Training programs are implemented for officers and medical professionals to educate them on recognizing signs of combat stress and making referrals for follow-up care. The Secretary of Defense implements training programs for medical professionals and frontline providers to educate them on combat stress signs and risks, including substance use conditions. Members of the Armed Forces and their families are educated on recognizing combat stress signs, provided with pre-deployment stress management training, and given access to programs and treatment options to mitigate the negative impact of combat stress. The Secretary of Defense collaborates with the Department of Veterans Affairs and the National Institutes of Health to research and implement best practices for information dissemination to various military personnel and their families. SEC. 4. Evidence-based research and training. The Secretary of Defense will establish a working group with other agencies to research and develop measures to reduce the likelihood of combat personnel developing post-traumatic stress disorder. Additionally, a Peer-Reviewed Research program will be established to focus on preventive and early intervention measures within the Defense Health Program. The Secretary of Defense will establish a working group with other agencies to research and develop evidence-based preventive measures to reduce the likelihood of combat personnel developing post-traumatic stress disorder. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2007 for this purpose. The Secretary of Defense will submit an annual report to Congress on the status of research, plan implementation, and the impact on psychological casualty rates. The Secretary of Defense will facilitate investigators funded under this section to work with active-duty military personnel in their research.
